{"step_by_step_thinking": "The question asks about what the dentist will see when examining the edentulous mouth of an aged patient wearing a complete maxillary denture against six mandibular teeth. To answer this question, we need to analyze the relevant documents and look for information about the characteristics of edentulous mouths and the effects of wearing dentures. Document [4] mentions that factors that adversely affect successful use of a complete denture on the mandible include reduced support area, which can be caused by the mobility of the floor of the mouth and thin mucosa lining the alveolar ridge. Document [8] states that the absence of posterior occlusal contacts may result in increased anterior occlusal contacts and forces between natural mandibular dentition and artificial maxillary dentition. Document [11] discusses the psychology and personality of geriatric edentulous patients, which may be relevant to understanding their oral health. Based on this information, it is likely that the dentist will see a decrease in interocclusal distance when examining the edentulous mouth of an aged patient wearing a complete maxillary denture against six mandibular teeth. This is because the absence of posterior teeth and reduced support area in the mandible can lead to increased anterior occlusal contacts and a decrease in the space between the maxillary and mandibular dentures.", "answer_choice": "D"}
